titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. V:30. A Succession of visitors at the Office. Paul Brown a poor ignorant man, exceedingly intent upon the universal circulation of knowledge, by means of a subscription to furnish every town, village and hamlet through the United States with a free library. Azor Orne who was an Officer in the late army came to apply for an office as Consul at any South-American fort or in the Island of Cuba, at Matanzas— He had an earnest recommendation from W. King the Florida Treaty Commissioner, and he had been personally to the President, from whom he had obtained what he thought a promise, if there was a vacancy at Matanzas. There was a Mr D’Arcy of Baltimore appointed to that place a year ago— But upon application for it, from another person last April, it appeared D’Arcy had not gone from Baltimore. Upon being written to he had answered he would go in June— Orne said he would ascertain whether he was gone. Alexander Davy a Son of our Consul for the Port of Hull in England came with a Letter from his father— He is going to Carthagena, and wishes to be appointed Consul there— Dr Watkins came about his Accounts as Secretary to the Florida Treaty Commission— Mr Hunter of Rhode-Island, called with a claim of the widow of the late Commodore Perry, for compensation for his service in going to Angostura— I thought it had been settled; but no charge of it is to be found in the Accounts. Hunter is here upon a claim before the Florida Treaty Commission; and came just in time to see them adjourn. He said he was a good hunter, to be in at the death— I received from Boston, Jonathan Russells reply to my Remarks upon his Letters, communicated to Congress— It is published in the American Statesman, a Newspaper printed at Boston, of which Henry Orne is the Editor— The paper is of the 27th. of June. Orne is a young lawyer of some talents and a political adventurer of whom W King has made a partizan for Crawford, for the succession to the Presidency. Russell’s reply is as full of falsehoods and misrepresentations as his Letter from Paris— But he admits the interpolations in his duplicate— He attempts to represent me, as having tricked him into the delivery of his Letter at the Department as a duplicate; and having no sort of regard to truth he has made up a plausible tale of new accusation against me, to which I must Again reply. It is a great mortification to me, to have a large portion of the time which ought to be devoted
to the discharge of my public duties, absorbed in necessary self-defense— This is a miserable plot against me, devised by Clay at Ghent and in which he has made a tool of Russell. Clay and Russell are the Eagle and the worm of Herder’s fable. Clay soars and Russell crawls to the top of the mountain. I began upon a rejoinder to Russell’s paper this Evening.

2. VI:15. Bathed in the Potowmack this morning with Johnson Hellen— George being not very well did not go. Mr Tazewell and Mr W. King two of the Florida Treaty Commissioners called at the Office to take leave. They have adjourned till September. Mr King had some Conversation with me concerning the difference between the American and British Commissioners, under the 5th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent. I told him of its present situation, and prospects— The stipulation of the Treaty was that if the Commissioners should disagree upon their Report, it should be referred to the decision of a friendly sovereign. But as this must be attended with great difficulties, we proposed to the British Government to make a previous effort to adjust the affair by Negotiation— To this the British Government have agreed, but with a notification that they are not disposed to yield upon the point made by their Commissioner on this Article, as they had with regard to the sixth—which seems almost equivalent to saying that it is useless to negotiate. I told King that I expected we should be obliged to resort to the umpire, and that it would be necessary to resort to some mode of obtaining his decision. I had thought of proposing that it should be by a Commission of three persons, one to be appointed by the British and one by the American government, and the third by the umpire— The Commissioners to sit in this Country, and to make to the umpire sovereign the report, upon which his decisions should be founded— Mr King approved very warmly this proposal— Mr Rice and Dr Sewall called this morning at my house—upon the project of raising a loan for the Columbian College—

3. V: Bath in the river— The Summer heat has set in with the new Month intensely. My accounts are at length settled, and the Warrant for my last Quarter Salary has been furnished me. Those for the first quarter of the year, and for the balance due on my old Account for service in Europe being still delayed, I called this morning upon the Comptroller Anderson, who finally gave me one of the warrants and soon afterwards sent me the others— I have kept five years out of the balance due to me, by official chicaneries, and should have been kept out of it years longer, but for the clause in the appropriation Act of the last Session of Congress, that no person in arrears to the Government should be paid for his current Salary— On this clause they have withheld my Salary these six Months— I had pressed for a Settlement within half a year after my return to this Country, and repeatedly since that time— The question about a half outfit upon the Mediation Mission was made against me, and although the Comptroller told me time after time that the Constitution and Law were in my favour, yet he would not settle my account on that principle— He required the Sanction of the Secretary of State or of the President. I could not give it in my own case, and the President declined giving it from a scruple of delicacy from my present official connection with him. But after the Act of Congress of the last Session it became absolutely necessary. He took the official opinion of the Attorney General upon it, which was decisively in my favour, and thereupon decided— Anderson said he supposed they would bring it up at the next Session of Congress but I should be the only person in the transaction against whom they could make out nothing from it— At the Office there came a Mr Marple of Baltimore with a Letter from Mr D’Arcy mentioning that he had finally concluded not to go to his Consulate and recommending Mr
Marple for the appointment in his stead— I told him there was a prior application, thinking of Orne— Governor Preston also came. He has been appointed a Commissioner of Land claims in Florida— There was a Mr Westcott from New-Jersey who brought me a Letter of introduction from Mr Southard the Senator from that State.

4. V:30. Independence Day. Bathed in the Potowmack— Rain, great part of the day. I rode up to the Capitol, where the Declaration of Independence was read by Dr Watkins preceded by a few extemporaneous remarks— Mr Hawley the Church Clergyman made a prayer, and there was musick by the Band of the Marine Corps— As I was walking homewards from the capitol, Mrs Calhoun stopped her Carriage, took me in and set me down at my house— Mr and Mrs Gadsden were with her— She wanted me to spend the Evening at her house— After returning home I was occupied with the mail, till four O’Clock, when I went and dined with the party at Strother’s— The company did not exceed forty in number— The new Mayor, Carbery presided, and Genl. Van Ness was the Vice-President. Baron Stackelberg the Swedish Charge d’Affaires was the only diplomatic guest and Mr Petry the French Consul General was there— The Baron de Neuville with his family left the City the day before yesterday. The four Secretaries were at the dinner, which was as dull as usual— The heat was intense— Mr Carbery late to begin, and slow in following up the regular toasts— Stackelberg and Petry left the table before the volunteers commenced— I gave “The American hemisphere and the declaration of Independence— A new world of matter for a new world of Mind.” Crawford’s was a Sentiment of conciliation between the General and State Governments— Calhoun’s the Cause for which Warren bled, and Washington triumphed—and Thompson’s was upon Agriculture, Commerce, and manufactures— As soon as these were gone through the heads of Departments retired; I walked to Mr Calhoun’s and Spent the Evening there; with Mr and Mrs Gadsden— My Son George and Johnson Hellen dined with a party of young men at Georgetown.

5. V:30.Mr Crawford and his family left the City this morning for a visit to Georgia. I was without interruption at the Office, and wrote short Letters to my wife and to Degrand at Boston— I deposited at the Bank of the Metropolis the Warrants for the Balances due to me upon my Accounts, with much satisfaction that those of my last service in Europe, are at length closed— I have had occasion through the whole of this transaction, to observe the necessity, not only of a just cause, but of continual wariness, discretion, firmness and perseverance, to avoid inextricable entanglement in a case, itself perfectly clear— Upon the Call from the House of Representatives at the last Session of Congress, for the sums paid to Ministers abroad since the year 1800, a call which was to be answered by the Secretary of State, but from returns made up at the Treasury, the first return from the Register’s Office, exhibited me, as having been paid only half an outfit upon the Mediation Mission— This was directly contrary to the fact; but if I had reported to the House, the return as I received it, I should have been debarred from disputing it afterwards— It was with the utmost difficulty that I obtained the rectification of this mis-statement— Not till after I had sent it back to the Treasury, three or four times for amendment— Not until I had declared that if it was not amended to state the fact as it was, I should in reporting it to the house point out its inaccuracy, as it related to myself— Mr Nourse the Register then came to me, and agreed to make a new return conformable to the fact— The error was not only a mis-statement in itself, but it gave a false colouring to the statement of my own account, in the very point upon which the question was made— For by representing me as having been
paid only half an outfit upon the mediation Mission, the residue which had actually been paid me, would have charged to me as a payment on my general account, and thus have presented a balance as due from me, instead of that which was really due to me. The obstinacy and the cunning with which this point has been maintained and managed against me these five years, has not been without design— Perhaps is not yet wholly unfolded.

6. VI: River bath, with the Spring-tide— At the Office came a Mr Sinclair—a young Mr Davy, son of the Consul at Kingston upon Hull in England, who wishes to obtain the appointment as successor to his father, he being willing to resign, in his favour— Mr Canning also came, and had much conversation with me, respecting the disagreement between the Commissioners under the 5th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent, and respecting the contemplated renewal of Negotiation for the suppression of the Slave trade— That is to obtain from us the stipulation admitting the mutual right of search. I told him I would enter upon this latter subject with him when he pleased, but hoped he would postpone it till cooler weather. As to the Commission under the 5th. Article of the Ghent Treaty, it would be occupation for the Summer to obtain a correct knowledge of the points upon which the Commissioners have disagreed, and after all, we should probably be obliged to take the course stipulated by the Treaty, of reference to a friendly Sovereign— I mentioned to him what I thought would be the most convenient mode of making this reference— By the appointment of three Commissioners, one by the Government of the United States, one by the British Government, and the third by the Umpire Sovereign— The Commission to sit in this Country, and the decision to be made, upon the Report of a Majority of them— Mr Canning did not state any positive objection to this proposal but it did not appear altogether to please him— There is a large trunk full of Books, thirty folio Volumes at least reported; with the disagreeing opinions of the Commissioners. The question upon the Construction of the first Article of the Ghent Treaty, was merely a question of the grammatical meaning of a written sentence. Nothing could be more simple, and a Sovereign could decide it in person as well as by Ministers or Commissioners— But a complicated question about the North west angle of Nova-Scotia, the Northwesternmost head of Connecticut river, the Geocentric Latitude, Charters of English Colonies, Proclamations and Acts of Parliament Geographical Surveys of North-American Wildernesses, and ridges of highlands dividing rivers that fall into the St. Lawrence, from those that fall into the Atlantic Ocean, it is impossible that a foreign Sovereign, absorbed in the Cares of his own Government, should have time, or be willing to take upon himself the labour, of acquainting himself with the merits of the dispute sufficiently to decide with justice, and in a satisfactory manner, either to himself or to the parties. Mr Canning proposes making a Northern tour this Summer. Mr Rice and Dr Sewall were at my house this morning; and asked my opinion whether they could propose to Mr Canning, and the other foreign Ministers, to subscribe to the loan for the Columbian College. I told them it was a subject upon which I could not advise them.

7. V:30. Attended Meeting, and heard Mr Little in the Morning from John 17.20.21. “Neither pray I for those alone, but for them also which shall believe on me through their word;— That they all may be one; as thou, Father, art in me, and I in thee, that they also may be one of us: that the world may believe that thou hast sent me”— It was an illustration of the Unitarian doctrine, arguing that the passages of Scripture in which Christ is said to be one with the father, are to be understood in the same sense, as in this text all believers in the Christian faith are said to be one— The Evening
Sermon was from James 4.16. “But now ye rejoice in your boastings: all such rejoicing is evil.” A moral dissection against vain-boasting. After the morning service I left a card at Governor Preston’s lodgings. Notwithstanding the heat of the weather, I spent all the leisure of the day in writing. But my Journal is adrift.

div.p: 8. IV:30. A multitude of visitors, both at my house, and at the Office— Two persons by the name of Smith, and a Mr Perkins— Dr Thornton— Mr Price and Dr Sewall, about the loan to the Columbian College— Edward Wyer, with news, never to be depended upon— In the Evening Mr Calhoun, and afterwards General Scott, with Mr Dick, the District judge of the United States in Louisiana— They came while Mr Calhoun was with me and interrupted our Conversation— The relations in which I now stand with Calhoun are delicate and difficult. At the last session of Congress he suffered a few members of Congress with an Irishman named Rogers, Editor of a newspaper at Easton Pennsylvania, at their head to set him up as a Candidate for the succession to the Presidency— From that moment the caballing in Congress, in the State Legislatures, in the Newspapers, and among the people against me has been multiplied tenfold— The Franklin Gazette of Philadelphia, under the direction of R. Bache, G. M. Dallas, J. Sergeant, and Ingham, in concert with Rogers, opened immediately upon me, and has kept up ever since an insidious fire against me— Calhoun’s partizans have countenanced it, and have been as busy as those of Mr Crawford in their efforts to degrade me in the public opinion. Meanwhile Calhoun has always professed to be a friend and admirer of mine, and to persons whom he knew to be my friends has said that he did not mean to be a Candidate against a Northern Man; & that he himself was decidedly for a Northern President. There was a time during the last Session of Congress when so large a proportion of members was enlisted for Calhoun, that they had it in contemplation to hold a Caucus formally to declare him a Candidate. But this prospect of success roused all Crawford’s and Clay’s partizans against him— The administration of his Department was scrutinized with severity sharpened by personal animosity and factions malice— Some abuses were discovered, and exposed with aggravations— Cavils were made against measures of that Department in the Execution of the laws, and brought the President in collusion with both houses of Congress— Crawford’s newspapers commenced, and have kept up a course of the most violent abuse and ribaldry against him, and his projected nomination for the Presidency has not met with scarcely any countenance throughout the Union— The principal effect of it has been to bring out Crawford’s strength, and thus to promote the interest of the very man whom he professes alone to oppose— Calhoun now feels his weakness but is not cured of his ambition. My personal intercourse with him is necessarily an intercourse of civility and not of confidence. The President returned this Evening from Loudoun.

9. IV:30. A Mr Etzler was here this morning, who thinks he has made some astronomical discovery to regulate the Calendar; and Governor Preston who is going as a Commissioner of Land titles in Florida. I went to the City Hall, to receive the interest upon Mrs Hellen’s Loan to the Corporation. But the Register was not there. I was at the President’s and informed him of the substance of my last conversation with Mr Canning— The theatre opened this Evening, and being a proprietor for two shares I have two free tickets for the Season, and attended with George— Saw Sheridan’s “Rivals, or a Trip to Bath”—and “the Review, or the Wags of Windsor”— The House was thin, and the heat annoying— The principal comic performer is Jefferson, who performed the parts ofin the Rivals, and of Caleb Quotem in the Review. Sir Anthony Absolute and Mrs Malaprop were amusing, but the performance altogether was wanting in Spirit.

10. VI:Coll. Constant Freeman the fourth Auditor of the Treasury came to the Office, and Mr. Parish the private Secretary of Mr Canning, with a copy of documents relating to the Slave Trade; extracted from Papers published by the British House of Commons— E. Vail came to enquire for papers relating to a claim of his father, before the Florida Treaty Commissioners— Mr Frye was at my house this Evening and invited us to dine with him to-morrow. He spoke of a collection of Roman Coins which he has to dispose of for a friend, and said he would send them to me, to examine. I wrote part of a Letter to my wife.

11. V: I was up in the Night, somewhat unwell; and continued slightly indisposed the whole day. The oppressive heat of the weather, and the toils in which I am struggling affect my Spirits and my health. I finished my Letter to my wife, and attended late, at my Office. I dined with Johnson Hellen, and my Son George at Mr Frye’s— And in walking home we were all thoroughly drenched by a severe thunder-shower. Notwithstanding which, as it held up, George went to the theatre— I remained at home and retired early to bed— Five years have this day past since Dr Tillary by way of felicitation upon my birth day, congratulated me upon being between fifty and sixty— I have now turned the half-way corner— They have been five memorable years of my life, and certainly the five most laborious of the whole— They have also been crowned with blessings for which I am gratified to the giver of all good— They have had their trials of many kinds among which the severest was the decease of my ever dear and lamented mother. I am now in the midst of another and far different trial— A trial for my character, before my Country. It is but one of many which are preparing for me, and through which I must pass as it shall please Heaven— The caballing against me is so extensive, and so many leading men in every part of the Union are engaged in it, that the prospect before me is not hopeful. This particular plot will in a great measure, though not entirely fail— Russell will be disappointed, and will have the public voice against him: but Clay for whom Russell has performed the part of the Jackall, will so far gain his point, that it will form a theme for prejudice in the Western and Southern Country against me. I have now the advantages of Russell entirely in my hands. But the main argument of my cause requires discretion and firmness, both in an eminent degree. My cause is the cause of truth, of honesty, and of my Country— There is hardly a bad passion in the human heart, but is arrayed against me— But in controversies of this kind, success depends much upon the manner in which it is conducted. I have now my own errors to dread more than the power of the adversary. A single false step would ruin me; I need advice very much; but have no one to advise me. I finished yesterday the draught of a rejoinder to Russell’s publication in the Boston Statesman of 27. June— But it replies only to his false statements of the manner in which his Letters were brought before the House of Representatives; and is already so long that it will with difficulty be crowded into one newspaper. I have so much more to say upon the subject, that it will at least fill another newspaper; and I am apprehensive the public will grow weary of the subject, before it can be fully laid open to them. I began this morning the draught of the sequel to my rejoinder.

12. V:30. I was at the President’s this morning, and he spoke to me of Mr Russell’s publication in the Boston Statesman of 27. June, which he said he thought a very feeble thing— He also told me that since this affair had come to be so notorious he had been recollecting the circumstances of his receiving Russell’s Letter, which had before passed away from his memory— He now recollected that on receiving it, he had been surprized and embarrassed at its contents. He had shewn it to Mr Madison, then President, and consulted with him what he should do with it. They were both of opinion that it ought not to be put on the files of the Department, and thus exposed to be
at some day made public. Its publication they thought could only produce mischief. They considered Mr Russell as a man, at the time of the Treaty of Ghent, very recently introduced into the public service; whose advancement had outstripped his Consideration in the public opinion, and who had thought he could best promote his own views, by attaching himself to the interests and gaining the friendship of Mr Clay. As to the proposal for continuing the right of the British to navigate the Mississippi, neither Mr Madison, nor he, the President had ever thought there was anything objectionable in it. He had no doubt that the object of bringing forward Russell’s Letter in Congress was to produce a prejudice in the Western Country, looking to future Events; but he thought it a very poor expedient, and that it would fail of producing the effort intended by it— This Evening Mr Frye brought me the Roman Coins of which he had spoken— There are 163 of them, all very small—with a manuscript description of them, and a printed volume also containing specifications of them.

13. V:30. I received despatches from Mr Middleton, our Minister in Russia, containing the decision of the Emperor, upon the question submitted to him by the Governments of the United States and of G. Britain, as to the construction of that part of the first Article of the Treaty of Ghent which provides for the evacuation of our territories, by the British forces without carrying away any Slaves. The decision is in our favour, but is expressed in language needing explanation more than the paragraph of the Article which was in question— I took the despatches to the President’s, and proposed to him that the decision should be published in the National Intelligencer of which he approved. Captain O’Brien was at the Office, pressing for the settlement of his Accounts, under the two Acts of Congress that he has obtained— A Mr Massey came also to the Office— There was a heavy rain this Evening, notwithstanding which George went to the Theatre; but the performance was postponed till Monday.

14. V. Heard Mr Little this morning from Isaiah 42.8. “I am the Lord; that is my name: and my glory will I not give to another”— This text sufficiently indicates the unitarian doctrine of the discourse— The afternoon sermon was from 1 Peter 5.5. “Likewise, ye younger, submit yourselves unto the elder. Yea all of you be subject one to another, and be clothed with humility: for God resisteth the proud, and giveth grace to the humble.” The Christian Religion is I believe the only one that teaches humility as a virtue and a duty. Its primitive meaning in the Latin language whence it was derived is prostration to the earth—and its meaning in classical Latin is always in an unfavourable sense— Synonymous with low, sordid and base. It was no Roman virtue. Its excellence as a Christian virtue, was that which characterizes all the morality of Jesus—whose whole system is founded upon the sacrifice of the selfish to the social passions— Humility before God had been inculcated in the Jewish Scriptures, and humility had been taught by Solomon, as a precept of worldly wisdom; to obtain honour— By Jesus Christ it was enjoined as a moral obligation; and his own example was given by him as the example of the virtue to be imitated by his disciples. It has been questioned by philosophical speculators whether the Christian system of morals has not laid too much stress upon humility, to the disparagement of the more energetic virtues— It has in this respect as in many others been much abused; but the example of Jesus as well as his doctrine taught fortitude and inflexibility to righteous purposes, not less than humility. This is one of the virtues which require the sacrifice of the natural propensities of the human heart, and which can be exercised only by exertions of self-controul: but it must be tempered with a firm and determined Spirit which will not suffer itself to be made the sport or the instrument of the vices of others— I wrote this day to R. Walsh, and to Mr James Lloyd at Boston.

15. IV:30. Bathed in the Potowmack this morning with my Son George and Johnson Hellen. Dr. Watkins and a Mr Neilson called upon me at my house— Mr Massey at the Office; and Mr Canning, who came to take leave— He departs to-morrow upon a tour for the summer, to Canada, and to the Eastern States. He had some further Conversation upon the proposals relative to the suppression of the Slave-trade; and upon the disagreement between the Commissioners under the 5th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent. I mentioned to him the suggestion that perhaps we might finally come to an adjustment by an exchange of territory which might accommodate the interests of both parties. I shewed him on the map, where the exchange was proposed. The proposal appeared to be unexpected to him, and not altogether agreeable— He spoke however of it with his usual reserve and caution— Evening at the Play. The Highland Reel— Little Red Riding-Hood; and the Rendez-vous, or Hide and Seek— The last an amusing farce— The rest dull—

16. VI:Johnson Hellen left us early this morning— He goes to Rockville, Montgomery County Maryland, to commence the practice of the Law— He has been residing with us about twenty Months; and reading Law in the Office of Mr Wirt the Attorney General— He is an amicable and well disposed young man, but without much energy of character— I advised him to go and settle in one of the western States; where he would find a field upon which he might lay a foundation for future usefulness and personal consideration— But he had not the Spirit of enterprize to undertake it. If he had the faculty of employing his time usefully he would succeed where he is going he might succeed, but I think he has not. His constitution is infirm and his health precarious— My good wishes in his favour are far more ardent, than my hopes— I parted from him with a pang, and his absence leaves a vacancy in the house which I shall sensibly feel— The President left the city for a short visit to his Estate in Albemarle County, Virginia; leaving his family here— I sent for Mr Gales of the National Intelligencer, and enquired if he would publish my Rejoinder to Russell’s publication in the Boston Statesman of 27. June. He engaged to publish the whole of it, with the Statements of Mr Brent and Mr Bailey, to-morrow. Mr Rice was at my house, and I subscribed a second time to the loan for the Columbian College. Captain O’Brien was at the Office, about the adjustment of his Accounts— Evening at the Play. Saw Marion, or the Hero of Lake George, written by M. M. Noah, and the Prisoner at Large— Marion is called a Historical National Play, and is about upon a level with She would be a Soldier of the same Author. Noah is a lively Newspaper writer, and has some dramatic talent; but his plays are beneath all criticism.

17. V:30. Bath in the river with George. My Rejoinder to Russell was published in the National Intelligencer of this Morning. Mr George Hay called upon me and told me that he had read it through with attention, and approved altogether its contents. But he intimated that he thought no further publication by me would be necessary. That it was impossible Russell should ever recover or redeem his character; and that it would be wasting time and words to put him down lower than he would be after this publication— I told him that this was my own impression— That I was aware nothing I could henceforth say would affect Russell’s character; and that so far as concerned him I should not wish to add another word— But his doctrines had not been thoroughly exposed— The public had not yet looked with much interest to that part of this discussion, and his sophistications had ever found countenance and support in the public Journals in various parts of the Union— I should therefore undertake a thorough examination and refutation of the doctrines of his Letter, which would require two or three papers as long as the one this day published; but as the public soon grew weary of controversies in newspapers, I was not determined as to the mode of publication which I should adopt— Mr Massey and Captain O’Brien were at the Office.

18. V:30.Commodore Rogers called this morning, and told me he was going to-morrow for Boston, to sit upon the Court of Enquiry ordered on the conduct of Captain Isaac Hull, as superintendent of the Navy-Yard at Charlestown— That he should pass through Philadelphia, and would call and see Mrs Adams there. This Court is called at the reiterated request of Hull, against whom there appears to be a strong prejudice at Boston, and in its neighbourhood— There have been abuses at that Navy Yard, and in the Navy Agency— An Enquiry into the conduct of Binney the Navy Agent, and a Report in his favour— Trials by Courts Martial of Captain Shaw Commander of the Ship Independence, 74 in Boston Harbour, and of Joel Abbot, a Lieutenant in the Navy—the first for contemptuous treatment of his superior Officer, and the second for slandering him, and sentences against them both— Notwithstanding which there have been strong and marked manifestations of public sentiment in favour of Shaw, and against Hull— Rogers told me that Jonathan Russell, who has been a witness upon Shaw’s trial, prevaricated in such a manner as to take away all credit from his testimony— That before the trial came on, Russell had spoken in the strongest terms to the Secretary of the Navy against Hull, and told him that all the charges against him, about extorting passage money from persons who went between France and England in the Frigate Constitution in 1811. were true. But that after receiving a Letter from G. Blake, Russell had totally changed his tone, and testified on the trial entirely in Hull’s favour— This affair grew out of bickerings between Shaw and Hull, about a broad Pendant on board of the Independence. Captain O’Brien was at the Office: still pressing for the Settlement of his Accounts— Evening at the Theatre— Colman’s Heir at Law—and the Wandering Boys, or the Castle of Olival, which is Les deux Petit Savoyards mongrelized into a miserable male drama— The Play was indifferently performed— Burkes Dr Panglos was a failure— Jefferson’sZekiel Homespun but half comic— They should have exchanged Parts.

19. VI:30. Bathed in the river with George yesterday, and this Morning— General Mason of Georgetown was at the Office with a Captain Simmes, a Master of a Vessel, lost upon rocks in the West Indies, and plundered by Pirates— Captain Simmes saved himself and his crew, by hiring a boat and men, who took them to Matanzas in the Island of Cuba. He there applied to the American Consul, for payment of the expenses he had thereby incurred: but the Consul did not think himself authorized to pay them. The men found their way to the Havanna, or ship’d as Mariners in Vessels bound to Europe or to the United States. Captain Simmes now applied for payment of his expenses from the wreck of his vessel to Matanzas— On looking into the Laws, I did not find authority for the Secretary of State to allow them; but there is a provision in one of the Acts which I thought gave the power to the Comptroller of the Treasury, and I referred Captain Simmes to him. Captain O’Brien was again at the Office. Mr Frye and Dr Thornton were at my house this Evening— Mr Frye came to know my opinion of the value of the Roman Medals and Coins that he had left with me, but I had not examined them; and he agreed to leave them with me a few days longer.

20. V:30. Bath with George— The last time that the present morning tides will serve— The day intensely hot, as it has been all the week— Fahrenheit’s thermometer this day at 94. Without interruption at the Office where I could do little or nothing. Evening at the Theatre— The Birth-day or the Reconciliation, by Dibdin, from the German of Kotzebue: and the Midnight Hour—from the Guerre ouverte, or Ruse contre Ruse of Damaniant: originally Spanish— I had seen both these Plays before— The first at New York on the 18th. November 1801 under the title of Fraternal Discord, in a Translation by Dunlop who was I think then a manager of the New-York Theatre— The principal part was then
performed by Hodgkinson, and I think it was the only time I ever saw him— The other Play I saw on the 29th. of November 1810. at the French Ambassador Caulaincourt’s at St. Petersburg— It was then remarked for its title—particularly by Bussche, the Westphalian Minister; being just at the turning time from the Alliance to the War, between Alexander and Napoleon.

21. VI. Heard Mr Little, from Revelations 12.7.8.9. “And there was war in heaven: Michael, and his angels fought against the dragon; and the dragon fought, and his angels— And prevailed not; neither was their place found any more in heaven— And the great dragon was castout, that old Serpent, called the Devil, and Satan, which deceiveth the whole world: he was cast out into the Earth, and his angels were cast out with him.” A mystical and difficult subject— The afternoon Sermon was from Hebrews 10.23. “Let us hold fast the profession of our faith without wavering; for he is faithful that promised.” Mr Petry, the French Consul General paid me a visit; between the services; and informed me of the departure of the Baron de Neuville, who embarked at New-York, for France on the 16th. A public dinner had been given him a day or two before in that city. Petry who has a pungent humour told me laughingly that the Count de Menou, who is left as Charge d’Affaires had gone with the Baron to see him safe on board ship, and was very impatient to have him fairly gone— In the leisure of the day I wrote to my wife.

22. V:30. A Mr R. Henry called upon me at the Office this Morning. He resides at St. Mary’s in Georgia, but belonged originally to the State of New-York, where he has now been, and is upon his return home from Albany. Mr Frye was at my house this Evening. He came to ask for the Roman coins, or to know what I would give for them. A hundred dollars was the price asked. I told him I would give 75 which I thought was as much as they were worth. I have examined a number of them— They are undoubtedly genuine, and are of various ages of the Roman History, from an early period of the Republic to the Antonines and later— They are all very small, of intrinsic average value of less than a quarter of a dollar. I promised to send them back to Mr Frye to-morrow. The Newspapers from the Neighbouring Cities notice my Rejoinder to Russell’s publication in the Boston Statesman; generally with approbation— Niles’s Register says that one of his neighbours called it annihilatory; but as an enemy cannot be more than annihilated, a question occurs whether further publication by me in the Newspapers would not be superfluous— Admonitions to that effect come to me from friend and foe.

23. V:30.Captain Douglas was at the Office, about a claim of Mrs. Ellicott the widow of the late Andrew Ellicott for services in attendance on the Commissions under the 5th. and under the 6th. and 7th. Articles of the Treaty of Ghent— There has been a question by which of the two Commissions his claim should be paid, which is not yet settled— I passed an hour this Evening at Mr Calhoun’s where I met again Captain Douglas— I wrote this day to my wife, and received another journalizing letter from her, giving her own opinion and that of a friend with whom she had conversed, dissuading me from further newspaper publication, upon the controversy— I am continuing however the discussion of the public topics so grossly misrepresented in Russell’s duplicate Letters. I will go through with them; and then determine whether to publish the whole, and how.

24. V:30.Lieutenant Gordon was at the Office, with a claim upon the Department, for having had Mr Shaler, the Consul General at Algiers, on board a vessel commanded by him belonging to the Squadron in the Mediterranean in 1819, for the space of a Month. One charge of this kind has already been allowed to Captain Ballard— At the time when the Plague was at Algiers
Shaler fled and was many months on board the Squadron, at Gibraltar, Marsailles, and Leghorn— He acted a Judge Advocate upon some Court-Martial, and took part in the differences between Captain Stewart and the Officers whom he sent home under arrest— This has been a charge upon the public, which has been referred from the Navy Department to the Department of State— So much of it has been allowed as could justly be considered in the light of extraordinary expense necessarily occasioned by the Plague— And also as much as was occasioned by extra-service, required by the Commander of the Squadron upon special emergency. The latter claim charged upon the Navy Department, and the former upon the Department of State— Shaler was on board of Gordon’s ship about a Month, and Gordon produces an order from Stewart to him to receive him. He has made a charge of 500 dollars for it, and is urgent for its allowance to meet a balance against him upon his accounts, under which by the Act of Congress of the last Session his pay is now stopped— Major Delafield the Agent under the Commission upon the 6th. and 7th. Articles of the Treaty of Ghent was at the Office with the Journal of the Commissioners who have completed their service on the 6th. Article, and are now to proceed upon the 7th. But he has not brought their accounts, which are indeed not made up: the reason for which Delafield states to be that since the agreement between the two Governments, that each should pay its own Commissioner, they had understood that this agreement extended also to the expenses of the Commission. The British Commissioner and his party incur considerable expenses, which General Porter does not incline to admit, yet against which he thinks it a matter of great delicacy to object. I told Mr Delafield, that the Agreement of the Governments was only for the Salaries of the Commissioners, it being expressly stipulated by the Treaty that the other expenses should be jointly and equally borne by the two parties. Delafield spoke also of their proceeding upon the Execution of the 7th Article, and said that some difficulties had arisen upon the description in the second Article of the Treaty of 1783. of the boundary line through Lake Superior, and thence to the Lake of the Woods— He said there was no Island in Lake Superior now known by the name of Philipeaux— That they could not ascertain what Lake was meant in the Article by the name of the Long Lake, and that the Article did not expressly indicate whether the water Communication between the Lake Superior and Long Lake was uninterrupted. I told him there could be no doubt of that and shewed him the original Mitchells map used at the Negotiation of 1783 for the delineation of the boundary, where the Long Lake is laid down in immediate communication with Lake Superior. Delafield had never seen this map, and said the Commissioners had not been able to obtain a copy of it. In the later maps, and particularly in Melish’s, there is no Long Lake laid down, and Delafield says that the whole topography of that part of Mitchell’s Map is imaginary. This must needs be the map having been published in 1785. before the Country had been explored— At this day, nearly seventy years later, it is still a land of Indian Savages. Delafield said it would be of use to the Commissioners to possess a copy of this map— Captain O’Brien was at the Office— In the Evening I walked down to Mr Frye’s— He had sent me back the Roman Coins which I took at the price I had offered for them.

25. VI:Lieutenant Gordon was again at the Office—very urgent to obtain the allowance of his charge on account of Mr Shaler— I told him it must be reduced by nearly one half, and that he must obtain from Mr Shaler, that he had been on board the ship upon special public service; to both which conditions he agreed. Delafield came again, and examined carefully the copy
of Mitchell’s map, which had been used at the Negotiation of the Peace in 1782. Evening at the theatre— Therese, The Orphan of Geneva a Melo drama, translated from the French of Victor, by John Howard Payne—and O’Keefe’s farce of Modern Antiques, or the Merry Mourners— The greatest portion of the pleasure which I now take in frequenting the theatre consists in the recollections of former occasions when I had seen the same Plays. Therese is a new piece— Brought out since I last returned from England, and the Melo-drama itself is a species of theatrical exhibition, invented I believe within the last twenty years. It is a mixture of Tragedy, Comedy, Opera and Pantomime, deeply interesting when well composed and well performed— But the instrumental music of the Melo drama is one of the essential ingredients of its pathetic power, and the Orchestra here being composed of five fiddlers is quite inadequate to produce any effect— The Melo-drama, exhibits situations of deep distress, of desperate danger—of malice, treachery, robbery and murder, at the most critical incidents of which the dialogue ceases, the scene passes in pantomime, accompanied by a strain of music from the orchestra, wild, irregular, and melancholy— The appeal to the sympathies of the Soul by instrumental music is forcibly illustrated by the Melo-drama; but our orchestra here is not in the Secret— The Modern Antiques, was the farce with which the first brick Theatre in Federal Street, Boston opened in February 1794. I was one of the original proprietors and builders of that Theatre, the erection of which was an incident of some note in the History of the town of Boston, as well as in that of my life— The association of remembrances connected with the performance of this farce at that time, with the Tragedy of Gustavus Vasa, three Nights successively. T. Paine’s prize Prologue, and all the discussion for and against the Theatre, which at that time occurred in Boston, is pleasing and mournful— I wrote this day part of a Letter to my wife.

26. V:30. I have been this day married 25 years. It is what the Germans call the Silber ne Hochzeit— The Silver Wedding— The happiest and most eventful portion of my life is past, in the lapse of those 25 years— I finished the letter to my wife. Looking back; what numberless occasions of gratitude! how little room for self-gratulation. Looking forward what dependence upon the overruling power! what frail support in myself— Time and the hour, wear through the roughest day— Let me have strength but to be true to myself, to my maker, and to man—adding Christian meekness and charity to Stoic fortitude— And come what come may— Mr Strawbridge, Edward Wyer and Captain O’Brien were at the Office— Mr and Mrs Frye called here this Evening, and we spent a couple of hours with them at Dr Thornton’s.

27. V:45. A Mr Ward, from Cincinnati in the State of Ohio, but originally from Massachusetts came this Morning to my house, and afterwards to my Office. He was recommended to me some Months since, and is now going to England upon private business— He wished to have been appointed a bearer of dispatches, but there being no occasion for the employment of such a Messenger, he requested a Passport, and a Letter of Introduction to Mr Rush which I gave him. Mr Williams of Baltimore, one of the family transplanted to that place from Roxbury likewise called at the Office. George went to the Play— I spent the Evening at Mr Richard Forrest’s. Mr and Mrs Calhoun, Dr. and Mrs Lovell, the Thornton’s and Captain O’Brien were there— Mr Daniel Brent invited George and me to dine with him at his house in the Country to-morrow— Mr Calhoun is likewise going; and offered seats for us in his Carriage, which I accepted. He promised to call, and take us up at my house to-morrow, after the morning service, and the arrival of the Northern Mail. Mr Brent’s seat is in Maryland, about eight miles from the City. I received a Letter from Mrs. Adams as I now do almost every day— Journalizing.

28. V:30. Heard Mr Little from Acts 13.32.33— [“]And we declare unto you glad tidings, how that the promise which was made unto the fathers,—God hath fulfilled the same unto us their children, in that he hath raised up Jesus again; as it is also written in the second Psalm, Thou art my Son, this day have I begotten thee”— Soon after returning home, I received the Mail; and about 2 O’Clock Mr Calhoun called and took us in his Carriage to Mr Daniel Brent’s— The weather was intensely hot, and the Sun beaming unclouded so that we were about two hours upon the road— We found there Coll. Freeman and Mr Pleansonton, Gales and Seaton, Mr Pearson, and his daughter, and Miss Brent a daughter of William Brent’s— We had a pleasant dinner, and a little, not much Conversation— We returned early in the Evening to the City. Mr Calhoun said much to me on the way, of the opposition to the Administration, combined by Mr Clay and Mr Crawford, each having separate views of his own. He spoke also of the absolute necessity that there should be in this District, an Independent Newspaper, to expose the intrigues of those Gentlemen to the Nation— The City Gazette is known to be under the management of Clerks in the Treasury— It has been several months incessantly scurrilous and abusive upon Calhoun; cautiously and equivocally so upon me; and without avowing its devotion to Crawford, occasionally disclosing it in a manner not to be mistaken— Its Editor is an Englishman—having no character of his own—penurious and venal— Metal to receive any stamp; and as his Treatment now of Crawford and me, looking like one of the Tower-stamped dollars during the late War, with George the third’s head struck over that of Charles the fourth, and not entirely effacing it. The National Intelligencer, is also in subjection both to Clay and Crawford, by the Act of Congress which Clay carried through, under which the Printers of Congressional documents for every Congress, are chosen by the preceding Congress— Calhoun thinks that this gave the Speaker of the House absolute control over the National Intelligencer Newspaper, both as a rod over the heads and a sop for the mouths of its Editors; and he has no doubt it was Clay’s object in carrying the Law— By making them dependent upon Congress, it palsied them at least, as supporters of the Executive— They incline also from other motives towards Crawford; and although uncertain which will be the strongest side, and therefore wishing to keep themselves neutral as much as possible, they will while endeavouring to avoid direct commitments of themselves, lean as much as they can, in favour both of Crawford and of Clay. An Independent Newspaper therefore is indispensable said Calhoun, and he asked me what I thought of M’Kenney’s Prospectus— I thought an Independent Newspaper would be very necessary to make known the truth to the People; but I said I was not acquainted with Mr M’Kenney, and knew nothing of his qualifications for editing a paper, nor of his Independence— His prospectus was well written, and opened an excellent plan as that which he should pursue— But he must have a heart of oak, nerves of iron and a Soul of Adamant to carry it through— His first attempt would bring a Hornet’s Nest upon his head, and if they should not sting him to death or blindness, he would have to pursue his march with them continually swarming over him, and beset on all sides with Slander, Obloquy and probably assassination— Calhoun thought this picture highly coloured, but admitted there was reason to foresee a stormy career for M’Kenny. I doubt much however whether Mr M’Kenney’s paper will be Independent. I think it originated in the War-Office, and will be Mr Calhoun’s Official Gazette, as long as it lasts. Whether it will live through a Session of Congress, is to be seen; but if it fulfills the promise of its prospectus it will pass through more than fire if it does. It is to be an Evening paper, twice a week, and the first number is to be published the 7th. of next Month. Mr Calhoun evidently considers
his future prospects, and even his continuance in the present Administration as depending upon it— Opposite the Post-Office, I alighted with George, and we walked home.

29. V:30. Bathed in the river with George— Coll. Bomford was at the Office, with a claim in behalf of the heirs of the late Mr Barlow, for an additional allowance on account of his Salary as Minister to France, in 1811— His account has been some time settled at the Treasury; and the question was at what time his Salary should commence— He had been appointed several Months before he embarked— The rule originally adopted during the Administration of President Washington was that the Salary should commence at the time when the person appointed left his home to proceed upon his Mission— In several instances this had been extended to the time when they broke up their household establishments previous to their departure; and this was done in the case of Mr Barlow. But in some cases, particularly of members of Congress who resigned their Seats on accepting their appointments, the Salary has commenced from the time of the appointment— This having been discovered, by Mr Barlow’s Representatives they now claim that his account should be reopened to make him a further allowance for Salary, from the time of his appointment, until that of his breaking up house keeping at Kalorama, at which his Salary commenced, by the Settlement at the Treasury— There are two objections to it—one to the reopening a settled account, for any other purpose than of correcting an error: and the other, that Mr Barlow’s case does not come within the principle of those in which the allowance has been made from the time of appointment—namely the resignation of another office, and the cessation of its endowments— Captain O’Brien and E. Wyer, were likewise at the Office— I passed the Evening at Mr Frye’s.

30. V:30. River-bath with George. At the Office, came Mr Whitney of New-Haven, the inventor of the Cotton-gin; and Captain O’Brien, still for the settlement of his Accounts. The two Acts of Congress already passed in his favour, are not sufficient to cover his claims; and he is indefatigable in his siege upon me to obtain more than Congress have yet been willing to give him— There was an Evening party at Dr Lovell’s, which I attended— The party was small— Mr Meigs the Commissioner of the Land-Office was there, and told me he was going to-morrow Morning to spend a few days at Philadelphia— I asked him to call and see Mrs Adams which he promised— George went to the Play.

31. V:30. Potowmack Bath with George— The day passed without interruption at the Office. I dined with George at Mr Frye’s. George Johnson was there— After dinner, Mrs Frye having retired to the parlour, I left the table and joined her, where being alone with me she inquired if I had ever spoken with disapprobation of her marriage with Frye. I was surprized at the question, and assured her that I had not— She had been told that I had; and in terms which would have been as unbecoming in me, as mortifying to her— I immediately named to Mrs Frye the person who had told her this, which she did not deny; but said she could not tell me who it was— I assured her it was utterly false— That far from disapproving her Marriage, I had been much gratified when informed of it. Having always respected the character of Mr Frye, and having a regard for him which has increased the more I have known him— There is the venom of vipers in such tongues as these. This has been rankling for years in the mind of Mrs Frye; and in all probability in that of her Husband. There was not the shadow of a foundation for it— But it was said to gratify some momentary malice, and a natural propensity to mischief-making— Walk home.

Day. Rise between 5 and 6. Breakfast about 9. Write till between 1 and 2. attend at the Office till 5 or 6. dine, and thence spend the Evening, walking or sitting at a window or at the Street
door without Candles— Occupation, either of reading or writing, I find impracticable, for the heat and the bugs. Occasionally I attend the Theatre— I have been however deeply engaged the whole Month in my controversy with Jonathan Russell. I received on the first day of the Month his publication in the Boston Statesman of 27 June, and replied to it in part by a paper in the National Intelligencer of the 17th. I then promised another, but in taking up and discussing thoroughly the topics of his Letter of 11. February 1815 from Paris, I have found it necessary to write three papers each of them too long for publication in one Newspaper— I have this day finished the first draught of the last of those papers— But the arrangement is yet to be completed, and some additions and some retrenchments are to be made— But in the present Stage of the controversy the public Sentiment is almost universal against Russell; and very strongly expressed— A Volume more in the newspapers would weaken instead of strengthening that impression— It could look like mangling a fallen enemy— I have no such inclination, and have no wish to exult over him— But the doctrines of his Letter must be put down. I think of publishing a pamphlet— The writing of these papers has totally absorbed all my morning hours, that my Diary has been running the whole Month in arrears.
